title: Rory Stewart accused of racism for calling three black men ‘minor gangsters’
text:
Rory Stewart referred to a trio he had met in a campaign video as ‘minor gangsters’ (Picture: Peter Summers/Getty Images/Anas Chowdhury/@RoryStewartUK)

London mayoral hopeful Rory Stewart has been accused of racism after describing three men he met in a campaign video as ‘minor gangsters’.

Labour MPs have slammed the former Tory cabinet minister for stereotyping the trio, who he approached while vying to replace Theresa May as party leader over the summer.

The three men, who are an Irish hip-hop act, said the comments ‘come from a racist place’.

Stewart received praise and ridicule alike after the awkward encounter filmed on Brick Lane admitting ‘you can’t win ‘em all’ when he posted the clip on social media.

The trio identified themselves as from Ireland but did not mention what they do for a living.

Hare Squead member Lilo Blues said the remarks came ‘from a racist place’ (Picture: @RoryStewartUK)

According to the Guardian, Stewart referred back to the clip at an event in London’s Emmanuel Centre.

He said: ‘One thing about social media is that it allows people to see politicians listening.

‘I can go to Brick Lane and three sort of minor gangsters can come up to me and spend a minute telling me I’m an idiot.

‘And I can film it on my phone and put it up. And people love watching people being rude to politicians.’

In response to the report, Labour MP Diane Abbott tweeted: ‘This is racism. And it is completely shameful. Especially when it comes from someone running to be the mayor of our diverse and multicultural capital city.’

Fellow party member and MP David Lammy also tweeted to suggest Mr Stewart was ‘compounding stereotypes’.

But one of the men in the clip laid out his account of the exchange on Twitter, revealing the trio to be Jessy Rose, Tony Konstone and Lilo Blues of Dublin hip-hop outfit Hare Squead.

Describing Stewart as ‘some corny-looking opportunistic goof’, Mr Blues accused the former cabinet minister of singling them out to make ‘good content’.

The ‘fake gang signs’ the trio made to the camera were clearly for ‘banter’, he added.

Hare Squead member Lilo Blues relayed his side of the encounter on Twitter

In a statement to TheJournal.ie, Hare Squead added: ‘He’s trying to be the mayor of one of the most culturally rich and ethnically diverse cities in the world, and yet to him we’re just props for his content.

Advertisement

‘We walked away from him, not just because we aren’t actively engaged in politics, but also because we knew he was just trying to use us.’

‘For him to turn around now and call us “minor gangsters” just adds insult to injury, and definitely comes from a racist place. We’ve always made positive music, mostly love songs.’

Apologising over Twitter Stewart said: ‘I hope anyone who has watched the video will understand I was describing a light-hearted encounter in which some men were – completely understandably- gently mocking me.

‘I was trying to describe the incident to an audience that hadn’t seen the video in order to poke fun at myself as a politician in an awkward encounter.

‘I am really sorry for causing offence. Thank you also to @DavidLammy for raising this too. I am really sorry.’

Rory Stewart quit to stand for London Mayor, and will campaign against Tory candidate Shaun Bailey, pictured right (Picture: Rex Features)

Asked whether he was sorry for stereotyping the men or merely that his comments caused offence, he added: ‘I am very sorry towards the guys and towards everyone else. I was wrong.’

Stewart was an outsider in the Conservative leadership race but boosted his profile with a series of pop-up events and walks to meet ordinary voters, some of which were filmed and posted on social media.

He was one of 21 Tory MPs kicked out of the party after supporting legislation aimed at blocking a no-deal Brexit.

description: London Mayoral candidate Rory Stewart was accused of racism for calling a trio in a Tory Party leadership campaign clip 'minor gangsters.'
